abstract.para: This chapter describes Combustion‐the tool used to configure your system according to your configuration on first boot.

sect1.title: About Combustion
sect1.para: Combustion is a dracut module that enables you to configure your system on first boot. Combustion reads a provided script and executes commands in it and thus perform changes to the file system. You can use Combustion to change the default partitions, set users' passwords, create files, install packages, etc.

Combustion is a dracut module that is invoked after the ignition.firstboot argument is passed to the kernel command line. Combustion then reads configuration from script. If the network flag has been found in script, Combustion tries to configure network. After /sysroot is mounted, Combustion tries to activate all mountpoints in /etc/fstab and then call the transactional-update to apply other changes (like setting &rootuser; password or install packages).

When using Combustion, you need to label the configuration device to combustion, create a specific directory structure in your configuration media and include a configuration named script.
